title: 111_s953
content: The Act may be cited as the "Seasonal Influenza and Pandemic Preparation Act of 2009" and includes a provision for a free influenza vaccine program. The Secretary will establish a national voluntary influenza vaccination program for adults and children, allowing individuals to receive the vaccine at no cost from various healthcare entities. Participating entities will be reimbursed for vaccine administration costs by the Secretary at a determined rate. The Secretary will award grants to facilitate the establishment of influenza vaccination programs in partnership with various healthcare entities. Participation in the program is voluntary and entities cannot charge co-payments or apply cost-sharing requirements for vaccine administration. The establishment of influenza vaccination programs in partnership with private entities, including retail outlets, pharmacies, faith-based organizations, private employers, and others as determined appropriate by the Secretary. Vaccination provided under a grant shall be at no cost to the individual. Entities participating in the program may request reimbursement from the Secretary. $500,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010, with additional funds as needed for each subsequent year. The Secretary shall award grants to public entities like local health departments, hospitals, and health centers to develop influenza vaccination programs for students and families in partnership with educational institutions. Vaccinations provided under the grant must be free of charge to individuals. Additionally, grants will be awarded to schools for the same purpose. The Secretary will award grants to schools for a voluntary influenza vaccination program, with vaccinations provided at no cost to individuals. $150,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010, with additional funding as needed in subsequent years. The Secretary will also develop immunization plans with target numbers for populations served under specific programs, providing bonus payments to eligible healthcare providers. The Secretary will provide bonus payments to eligible healthcare providers and entities meeting immunization targets established in plans. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will establish a national public affairs campaign to increase influenza immunization rates. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010, with additional funding as needed in subsequent years. Definitions include the national voluntary influenza vaccination program and the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
